awd_titl_txt: Elucidating the Thermodynamic and Kinetic Properties of High Temperature Materials with First-Principles Statistical Mechanics
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY 

Remarkable levels of sophistication have been reached in linking properties of a given material to its microstructure, crystal structure and electronic structure. A substantially bigger challenge, though, is predicting the dynamic evolution of a material taken out of equilibrium and determining what external stimuli must be imposed to shepherd the material into a desired end state. The desirable properties from a particular chemistry are usually manifested in metastable crystal structures and microstructures rather than in the true equilibrium state of that chemistry. In many applications it is necessary to know how a material in a particular state will evolve over time either because it is metastable or unstable, such as in high temperature applications, or due to changing boundary conditions, as in electrochemical energy storage applications.

This award supports computational research and education to develop highly automated statistical mechanical software tools that will be used to predict materials properties and greatly enhance the ability to design materials for high temperature and non-equilibrium applications from first principles. Areas where such tools will prove invaluable include the design of new (i) structural materials for aerospace applications and large-scale power generation plants, (ii) electrode and electrolyte materials for electrochemical energy storage, (iii) materials for thermoelectric applications and (iv) materials for shape memory applications. The project will also involve the education and training of graduate students in computational materials science, a field that is increasingly recognized as invaluable in the design and rapid implementation of new materials.

TECHNICAL SUMMARY 	

This award supports research and educational activities aimed at extending the existing thermodynamic and kinetic foundations that underpin phenomenological descriptions of non-equilibrium processes in the solid state. This will be realized by two activities: (i) the development of statistical mechanical computational tools to automate the calculation of a wide variety of thermodynamic and kinetic properties that are essential in the description of materials evolving out of equilibrium and (ii) the development and application of new statistical mechanical theoretical methods to enable the prediction of high temperature properties of multi-component crystalline solids.
 
A deep understanding of many high temperature materials and non-equilibrium processes is hampered by a lack of not only quantitative thermodynamic, kinetic and mechanical data, but also a lack of knowledge about qualitative trends in this data. Furthermore, a large class of technologically important high temperature materials cannot be adequately described and understood with current statistical mechanical methods. This research activity will result in highly automated computational statistical mechanical tools to predict free energies and transport coefficients as a function of concentration. Such tools will provide new knowledge about the dependence of a wide variety of materials properties on chemistry and crystal structure. The theoretical focus on high temperature phases will generate fundamental new insights about the vibrational stabilization mechanisms, atomic hop mechanisms and mechanical properties of a large and important class of poorly understood materials used in high temperature applications.  The project will also involve the education and training of graduate students in computational materials science, a field that is increasingly recognized as invaluable in the design and rapid implementation of new materials.

por.por_cntn:
First-principles electronic structure methods have reached a remarkable level of sophistication and accuracy. Many basic properties of new and existing materials can be predicted rapidly. This is now exploited in high-throughput schemes to search for new battery, photovoltaic and thermoelectric materials. Most applications, however, rely on complex materials properties that are not directly accessible with current first-principles electronic structure methods. Properties that must be optimized are often sensitive to temperature, making entropy an important quantity to take into consideration. Major challenges also remain in modeling the dynamic evolution of a material taken out of equilibrium.

The objective of this project has been to extend existing thermodynamic and kinetic foundations that underpin phenomenological descriptions of materials properties and to connect these descriptions to the underlying electronic structure of a material using statistical mechanics approaches. The project has led to the development of new methods and accompanying software to predict the thermodynamic and kinetic properties of crystalline materials that exhibit a range of excitations (configurational and anharmonic vibrational degrees of freedom) at elevated temperature. Special attention was devoted to generating a deeper understanding of crystalline phases that become dynamically unstable at low temperature.

A key underpinning of the project has been the development and application of methods to automate the construction of effective Hamiltonians (relying on group theoretical techniques of crystal symmetry), which extrapolate first-principles energies for a variety of atomic and molecular degrees of freedom. These degrees of freedom include configurational excitations (as in alloys and magnetic solids) and anharmonic vibrational excitations (relevant for structural transitions). The effective Hamiltonians are then subjected to (kinetic) Monte Carlo simulations to predict a wide variety of thermodynamic, kinetic and chemo-mechanical properties that can then be fed into well-established continuum simulation approaches of dynamic evolution of non-equilibrium materials.

Specific project outcomes include:

-       Computational tools to predict temperature dependent properties of alloyed crystals, including metals, ceramics, semiconductors and quantum materials.

-       A deep understanding of the role of electronic and crystal structure on the finite temperature electrochemical properties of electrode materials for Na-ion and Mg-ion batteries.

-       The development of a fundamental understanding of the role of low temperature dynamical instabilities on structural phase transitions, which are of importance to many technologically promising materials such as halide perovskites.

-       The results of numerous first-principles statistical mechanics studies of technologically promising materials, which were disseminated in nine archival peer reviewed journal articles.   

-       The training of graduate students in computational materials science and software development.

The statistical mechanics methods and software tools developed in this project have broader impacts as they enhance the ability to design materials for high temperature and non-equilibrium applications from first principles, thereby reducing the time and cost to develop new materials. Areas where such tools will prove invaluable include the design of new (i) structural materials for aerospace applications and large-scale power generation plants, (ii) electrode and electrolyte materials for electrochemical energy storage, (iii) materials for thermoelectric applications and (iv) materials for shape memory applications. Advances in any of these areas will reduce environmental degradation, generate new economic opportunities and improve the general quality of life. Graduate students supported by this grant also participated in outreach activities that seek to encourage K-12 students from underrepresented groups to pursue a career in science and technology.
